message.content: This question requires knowledge about the water cycle and the properties of water. Even if a lake is frozen, it is still made up of water molecules. By melting the ice, you can obtain water from the lake. Option (B) is incorrect because if the lake is completely gone, there would be no water left to obtain. Option (C) is incorrect because when water evaporates, it turns into vapor and no longer exists as liquid water in the lake. Option (D) is incorrect because if the lake is dry, there is no water left to obtain.

This question tests knowledge of the water cycle and the properties of water. Even if a lake is frozen, water can still be obtained from it. When the frozen lake is heated or undergoes melting, the ice will turn back into liquid water, allowing for obtaining water from the lake. Options (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect because if the water is gone, evaporated, or dry, there would be no water left to obtain.

This question requires basic knowledge about the water cycle. Even if a lake is frozen, it still contains water. When the temperature increases, the ice will melt and become liquid water that can be obtained. Option (B) is incorrect because if the lake is gone, there is no water to obtain. Option (C) is also incorrect because when water evaporates, it becomes water vapor and cannot be directly obtained from the lake. Option (D) is redundant because if a lake is dry, there is no water to obtain.

Option (D) is incorrect because if the lake is dry, there is no water left to obtain.
